channel.title: Chemistry
channel.description:
This chapter in my Chemistry class has been very confusing to me, mainly because I never did quite understand the first concept of the chapter. Now, the problems are using multiple conversions in order to answer a question. I was wondering if someone could help me out with this question below:
Determine the limiting reactant and the mass of zinc hydroxide produced when 25.0 g Zn and 30.0 g MnO2 are used.
Zn + 2MnO2 + H2O --> Zn(OH)2 + Mn2O3 (The subscripts are after the element/compound)
I know how to find the limiting reactant, only by looking at a problem and applying that math to the other. If someone can help me out and explain how I can start off the problem, and why do I have to do that.

item.title: Chemistry
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Rix_:

Use the number of moles of the limiting reagent in your other calculations.

Thanks for the help. I finally figured out the overall concept of Stoichiometry today.

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Use the number of moles of the limiting reagent in your other calculations.

Read full topic
